items.content:

These let you define styles based upon the state of another element (such as whether a position: sticky-ed element is actually 'stuck' and how). Itâ€™s early days and Chrome Canary only for now, but this is a good initial look at theÂ concept.

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Create signup and login forms, reset passwords, generate magic links, add SSO with Google, and more. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor

Behind the Curtains of Wikipedia's Redesign â€” Shipping a redesign of one of the most visited sites on the web is no mean feat. Here, Alex Hollender and Jon Robson (from the team behind the effort) share details on the design, development, and process that went into theÂ project.

Geoff Graham INTERVIEW

Going Beyond Constants with Custom Properties â€” Some insights as to how we can use custom properties to â€œcreate some smart systems or even use them as booleans in CSS and create easy progressiveÂ enhancementsâ€.

Brecht De Ruyte

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Two version 4s this week, with Svelte 4.0 (the frontend framework) and Stencil 4.0 (the Web Components toolchain) both landing.

  • Support for the CSS @property at rule may be enabled in Firefox Nightly soon. Firefox has long been a hold out in browser support for this feature.

  • Alvaro Montoro is having fun creating single div CSS drawings. We like the Spirited Away and Game Boy pieces. One to use Inspect ElementÂ on.

All experimental stuff, but an excellent bit of testing with examples to play withÂ too.

Roman Komarov

Brian Smith

Ryan Trimble

Vivaldi on Why a Browser + Mail Combination is Great â€” Browser maker Vivaldi makes the case for browser with a built-in email client. To be fair, a good chunk of us probably use Gmail on the web, so sure, whyÂ not.

Daniel Aleksandersen

Form and Search Landmarks â€” A look at how well browsers and screen readers support the form and search landmark ARIAÂ roles.

Panda CSS: Modern, Build-Time, Type-Safe CSS-in-JS â€” From the mind behind the Chakra UI component library comes this new DX-focused CSS-in-JS framework. It boasts build-time generated styles and type safety out of the box. It works with Remix, Vite, Next.js, Astro, and even serverÂ components.

Segun Adebayo

WebPerf Snippets: A Curated List of Snippets to Use in The Browser to Get Performance Metrics â€” You can use these in the Chrome DevTools Sources tab or directly in your browserÂ console.

Joan LeÃ³n

ModHeader: A Browser Extension to Modify HTTP Request and Response Headers â€” The site includes related tools but the primary one allows you to modify HTTP headers for testing performance, mimicking requests from various locations/devices, debugging CORS issues, etc.

Hao Nguyen

Shiki: A Syntax Highlighter Using VS Code Themes â€” Supports over 100 languages and you can specify a VS Code theme in the settings to get the look you want. Works in both Node.js and even on static sites (via a CDN build) and you can see some examplesÂ here.

Shiki

Flowbite: Free and Open-Source SVG Icons â€” A collection of over 400 clean and clear icons that you can simply tap to copy the SVG codeÂ for.

Krall, Tanislav, SzÃ¶gyÃ©nyi

Starlight: Build Beautiful, High-Performance Documentation Sites with Astro â€” Includes a bunch of features out-of-the-box like site navigation, search, internationalization, code highlighting, dark mode, and itâ€™s extendible using your favourite framework (React, Vue, Svelte, etc).

Starlight

Missed last week's issue? These were the top three links shared inÂ issueÂ 598:

  • Chris Coyier shared five new CSS things that "really matter to real-world development".

  • Matthias Ott on the new powers found within CSS and how these changes make CSS "the most powerful design tool" for the web.

  • A mind-bending article from Roman Komarov on a unique CSS 'cyclic' toggling technique we're still getting our headsÂ around.

ğŸ™ˆ Try again...

The Password Game â€” Iâ€™m sure weâ€™ve all been there: you enter what you think is a solid password, and then the form decides to inform us of its arbitrary, mysteriousÂ rulesâ€¦ This is a tongue-in-cheek take on that, but turned up to 11. Good luck! (You should be using a password manager.. â€“ Ed)

Neal Agarwal

items.title: How do you use CSS?
items.content:
#â€‹598 â€” June 21, 2023 | Read on the web

Modern CSS in Real Life â€” Chris (of CodePen fame) runs through five modern CSS concepts that â€œreally matter to real-world developmentâ€, including logical properties, container queries, color spaces, and more. This is a real deep-dive highlighting the fast-paced changes we are seeing in CSS, with plenty of code, examples, and visuals to help thingsÂ along.

Chris Coyier

The 'State of CSS 2023' Survey is NowÂ Open â€” With a ton of new CSS features like :has(), subgrid, and container queries quickly gaining adoption the annual CSS survey from Devographics returns a bit earlier than usual. Hereâ€™s the announcement post explaining why you should fill itÂ out, and some background from this year's lead survey designer, Chen Hui Jing. As always, we recommend filling it out, and we'll be sure to go through the results once live.

Devographics

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Create signup and login forms, reset passwords, generate magic links, add SSO with Google, and more. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor

Cyclic Dependency CSS Variable Toggles â€” PaweÅ‚ Grzybek calls this â€œone of the most mind-bending CSS articles I have read in a whileâ€ â€“ weÂ agree. It's well explained but CSS custom properties are twisted â€“ nay, broken up â€“ into new shapes that it might take a little head scratching to figureÂ out.

Roman Komarov

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • The W3C has deployed its new website.

  • ...and the W3C has published a new web standard for online payments as a CandidateÂ Recommendation.

  • It's Cloudflare's "Speed Week" which means lots of Web performance related news, such as their full support for HTTP/3 Extensible Priorities, a new GraphQL 'Timing Insights' API, and the forthcoming automatic use of Early Hints and Fetch Priorities on pages they serve.

  • The humble PDF file format is 30 years old.

  • Opera One is now the new flagship browser from Opera.

  • Tyler Sticka asks: is there a viable animated GIF alternative yet?

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Positioning Anchored Popovers â€” Popovers are commonly positioned relative to their invoker â€” but when using the new popover attribute, anchoring can be tricky as these popovers are placed in the top layer, away from the context of their invoker. Hidde looks at what options we have to resolveÂ this.

Hidde de Vries

Thoughts from â€œMeet Safari for Spatial Computingâ€ â€” The key takeaway being that when it comes to visionOS you can continue doing â€œwhat responsive web design and accessibility experts have advocated for yearsâ€, and for the most part things will â€˜just workâ€™ on this newÂ platform.

Jim Nielsen

The New CSS â€” How recent tooling changes and new capabilities represent a â€œfundamental shiftâ€ for CSS, making it â€œnow the most powerful design tool for theÂ Webâ€.

Matthias Ott

A New Comprehensive Project Management Tool from Notion â€” Execute plans with speed and clarity with Notion's powerful new project management tools - the first with AIÂ assist.

Notion sponsor

Fit-to-Width Text â€” An active look at how scroll-driven animations will hopefully solve the â€˜fit-to-widthâ€™ text problem with just pureÂ CSS. (See also: This collection of related demos from Bramus Van Damme.)

Roman Komarov

â–¶Â Â Going Beyond Color Contrast â€” A quick introduction to tools that will help you automate the identification of accessibility issues beyond color contrast. Thereâ€™s an accompanying blog post too.

Schalk Neethling

â–¶Â Â Improving Performance for Three Million Sites â€” An interesting dig into how Shopify approaches performance challenges atÂ scale.

Michael Gooding

ğŸ” A FOCUS ON:
The :has() psuedo-class selector

The :has() CSS pseudo-class now enjoys widespread browser support, and can be used across Chrome, Safari, Edge, Opera, and others (Firefox has it behind a flag for now). It lets you style an element that contains a specific descendant, defined by a selector argument, and can be used in a variety of interesting, creative ways.

ğŸ“‘ â€” Related W3C spec and MDN documentation.

â“ â€” :has() Can I use... stats

An Introduction to :has() â€” Shares how the :has() pseudo-class has far greater range than just styling an elementâ€™sÂ ancestor.
Stephanie Eckles

Using :has() as a CSS 'Parent Selector' and More â€” Jen runs through the basics of how to use :has() as a parent selector with some practical examples. â€œThis feels like a revolution in how we will write CSS selectors...â€
Jen Simmons (WebKit)

The Advanced Guide to the CSS :has() Selector â€” Rahul looks at some advanced implementations and use cases for has, including checking for multiple children, conditional decorations, and styling emptyÂ states.
Rahul Chhodde

Style Your RSS Feed â€” How to make your RSS feed look nice (thanks to XSLT) and provide useful information at the sameÂ time.
Darek Kay

How to Watch Transitions in Slow Motion in Chromeâ€™s DevTools
Jim Nielsen

Six Quick Tests You Can Do to Test Your Forms for Accessibility
Karl Groves

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Frosted Glass â€” A lovely looking depth-based blur effect created with CSS. Hereâ€™s how it works, and some otherÂ examples.

Shu Ding

Motion Canvas: A TypeScript Library and Real-Time Preview Editor to Program Animations â€” Uses generator functions to procedurally define your animations, and you can try out the web-based editor that allows you to work with the animationsÂ visually.

Motion Canvas

SVG.js v3.2: SVG Manipulation and Animation Library â€” A lightweight approach without dependencies. Thereâ€™s a demo on JSFiddle you can play with. GitHubÂ repo.

Various Authors

Code Together Before You Work Together. Interview Devs in a RealÂ IDE â€” Skip algorithm interviews & use CoderPad to run coding interviews that are trusted by both candidates andÂ interviewers.

CoderPad sponsor

daisyUI: A Library of Tailwind CSS Components in MultipleÂ Themes â€” Includes dozens of ready-made components that you can try out using about 20 different themes, all of which are testable live in theÂ docs.

Redfern Dev

Threlte: A Three.js Scene Renderer and Component Library forÂ Svelte â€” react-three-fiber is great, but if you prefer Svelte, this is the alternative for you. It appears to be under very active development too with a whole new version on the way soon. GitHubÂ repo.

Grischa Erbe

Microsoft Clarity: Free Heatmaps & Session Recordings â€” A new, free user behavior analytics tool, that claims to be both GDPR & CCPA compliant â€”Â it helps visualize how users are interacting with your site through session replays andÂ heatmaps. Why is it free? Curiously, MS is upfront aboutÂ that.

Microsoft

Novel: A Notion-Style WYSIWYG Editor with AI-Powered Autocompletions â€” Built with Next.js, Tiptap, OpenAI (for autocomplete), and Tailwind. Try it liveÂ here.

Steven Tey

items.title: The gotchas of CSS nesting
items.content:
#â€‹597 â€” June 14, 2023 | Read on the web

Modern CSS for Dynamic Component-Based Architecture â€” Explores modern project architecture, with a focus on theming, responsive layouts, and component design. Stephanie looks at features we can use to improve code organization, digs into layout techniques (such as grid and container queries), and shares some real-world examples of context-aware components. A solid overview of how we can now approach things thanks to growing feature parity acrossÂ browsers.

Stephanie Eckles

Gotchas of CSS Nesting â€” Starting with a question with a surprising answer, Kilian explains how CSS nesting can lead to unexpected results due to how specificity can change when nested CSS rules are internally translated into individual rules forÂ application.

items.title: Preparing the web for spatial computing
items.content:
#â€‹596 â€” June 7, 2023 | Read on the web

ğŸ¥½ All the Browser and Web News from WWDC

Apple's annual developer conference is underway, and we've already had plenty of interesting tidbits and news shared (not least Apple's Vision Pro mixed reality headset). Spatial computing is their current phrase du jour, but what does developing web experiences for this environment look like? It's early days, but the sessions below provide a starting point and there's more on the way later thisÂ week:

  • ğŸ“„ WebKit Features in Safari 17 Beta
    â†³ An epic rundown of 88 new features coming to Safari later this year, including support for the popover attribute, Web Apps on the Mac, redesigned developer tools, and more.

    • â–¶ Meet Safari for Spatial Computing
      â†³ A 16 minute presentation on how Safari will work on the Vision Pro headset, how the navigation works, touching upon 3D web experiences, and how you can optimize your site for this upcoming platform.

      • â–¶ What's New in CSS
        â†³ A run through of the latest advancements in CSS, with a look at upcoming layout and typography features.

      • â–¶ Rediscover Safari Developer Features â€“ All about theÂ devtools.

A New Comprehensive Project Management Tool from Notion â€” Execute plans with speed and clarity with Notion's powerful new project management tools - the first with AI assist. Take notes, manage tasks, set goals, collaborate, and stayÂ connected.

Notion sponsor

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Also announced at WWDC, Safari 17 will add support for JPEG XL. Sadly, last year Chrome announced its intent to deprecate JPEG-XL support but this has led to some strong responses to reverse the decision: "Technically speaking, WebP is WAY behind JXL.."

  • CSS Nesting is now enabled by default in Firefox Nightly.

  • Version 14 of dev-focused browser Polypane is out now, with session management, a UI refresh, an element debug panel, bulk screenshots and more.

  • This is neat: draw something on the page and this site will return the closest Unicode character matches to your input.

  • A security.txt file is now mandatory for Dutch government websites.

  • ğŸ“… Tickets for the Fronteers Conference (returning in late September) are now onÂ sale.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

New CSS Color Spaces and Functions in All Major Engines â€” All three major browser engines now support the new CSS color spaces and functions â€” normalized ways to access colors within any RGB color space.

Rachel Andrew

An Introduction to @scope in CSS â€” A quick primer on how you can style based on proximity or by setting a lower boundary for aÂ selector.

Ollie Williams

Magical Rainbow Gradients â€” The human eye is particularly sensitive to movement in the field of vision â€” so you can use this technique that Josh shares here (by way of CSS Houdini and React Hooks) to add a dash of eye-catching action to an otherwise static element on yourÂ page.

Josh W. Comeau

How to Develop a Super App Using Open-Source Library Re.Pack â€” Sign up for a training program that will help you learn how to deliver features faster in complex teams orÂ products.

Callstack sponsor

Sharing WebSocket Connections Between Tabs and Windows â€” If your users open your app in multiple tabs or windows, being able to share a WebSocket connection could be a lot more efficient both at the client and server end. Is it possible? With SharedWorkers (supported by all major browsers except Chrome on Android), yes.

Szymon Chmal

Testing Sites and Apps with Blind Users: A Cheat Sheet â€” Things to consider for users of screen readers, often those with low vision andÂ blindness.

Shestopalov & Shykiriavyi

Watch Out for Layout Shifts with ch Units â€” Since ch units (most commonly the width of a '0' character) are based on your current font, their value can change when fonts are loaded, resulting in unexpected layoutÂ shifts.

Paul Hebert

Re-Evaluating px vs em in Media Queries â€” We used to say ems were the best unit to use in media queries. Is that still the case inÂ 2023?

Keith J. Grant

How Chrome Achieved High Scores on Three Browser Benchmarks
Thomas Nattestad

Three Ways to Find Your Worst JS Offenders for Page Load
Sia Karamalegos (Shopify)

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Hiber3D Development Kit: A JavaScript Library for Creating Web-Based 3D Experiences â€” Optimized for performance and includes built-in multiplayer, character controls, gameplay mechanics, React components, and an asset library of 500+ available â€œprefabsâ€. See examplesÂ here.

Hiber3d

NakedJSX: Use JSX without React â€” If you like JSX and would like to use it to help in the production of static HTML without using React itself, this command line tool is for you. It even extracted scoped CSS classes and deduplicatesÂ them.

David Hogan

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is theÂ Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, jest, karma, jasmine, andÂ more.

Wallaby.js sponsor

Materialize: A Responsive Frontend Library Based on MaterialÂ Design â€” More specifically, this is a 'community fork' of Materialize.css, an older unmaintained project, and includes quite a few components despite being listed as an â€˜alphaâ€™ release.

Materialize

Faker.js UI: Easily Generate Fake (but Realistic) Data for Testing and Development using Faker.js â€” You can try the interface here. Search for a specific data type and use the â€œGenerate Bulkâ€ option for each type to quickly spit out whatever amount of data youÂ need.

Joff Tiquez

ColourGPT: Use AI to Generate a Colour Palette Based on a Description â€” Type the number of colors you want and some keywords, for example, â€œ7 colors like the blue skyâ€ or â€œ5 colors in scarletÂ redâ€.

Bruce RÃ¶ttgers

SVG Gradients: A Gallery of 40+ Beautiful, Click-to-Copy SVG Gradients
Michael Andreuzza
